channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: Putin to Sign Ban on U.S. Adoptions of Russian Children
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said he would sign a bill banning adoptions of Russian children by American citizens, dealing a potentially grave setback to bilateral relations.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Russian President Vladimir Putin, right, with Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev, said today that he would sign a bill banning Americans from adopting Russian children.

item.title: Afghan Police, Betrayed in Sleep, Suffer Losses
item.description: The fear of insider attacks has been an even bigger concern for Afghan security forces than it has been for NATO and American forces.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: A graduation ceremony for Afghan police officers in the eastern city of Jalalabad on Thursday.

item.title: Rebels Move Toward Capital of Central African Republic
item.description: Thousands of civilians fled cities and towns into dense forest as embassies and humanitarian aid organizations evacuated many of their staff members from Bangui.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN and JOSH KRON

item.title: The iEconomy: Signs of Changes Taking Hold in Electronics Factories in China
item.description: After the hardships of workers in China’s electronics factories were exposed to a global audience, working conditions have changed.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHARLES DUHIGG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers assembling Hewlett-Packard computers at a plant in Chongqing, China, operated by Foxconn of Taiwan.

item.title: Syrian General in Charge of Stopping Defections Becomes a Defector
item.description: Maj. Gen. Abdul Azia Jassem al-Shallal is the highest-ranking officer to abandon President Bashar al-Assad.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Mannequins were set up to confuse snipers loyal to President Bashar al-Assad in the old city of Aleppo on Sunday.

item.title: Bolivia Reduces Coca Plantings by Licensing Growers
item.description: The world’s third-largest cocaine producer has taken an unorthodox approach to controlling the growing of coca that veers markedly from the wider war on narcotics.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Augustine Calicho, 45, separating the seeds from dried coca leaves in Villa Tunari in the Chapare region of Bolivia.

item.title: Iran’s Only Female Cabinet Minister Dismissed
item.description: Dr. Marzieh Vahid-Dastjerdi, who was appointed in 2009, apparently angered the president by criticizing the government’s response to acute shortages of medicine imports.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.N. Envoy Calls for Transitional Government in Syria
item.description: The envoy, Lakhdar Brahimi, said on Thursday that a transitional government should be granted full executive powers until new elections could be held.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Monitoring Mandela, and With Him the Soul of a Nation
item.description: After almost three weeks of treatment for a recurrent infection, Nelson Mandela, the 94-year-old icon of South Africa's triumph over apartheid, was discharged from hospital late Wednesday. But a terse statement from his physicians raised fresh questions.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Nelson Mandela in June 2010. More recent images are hard to come by.

item.title: Richard Baum, 72, Dies; Presided Over Chinapol
item.description: Mr. Baum presided over Chinapol, an online discussion group about China that has become an essential forum for many experts, diplomats and journalists.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Dr. Richard Baum presided over Chinapol, an online discussion group about China that has become an essential forum for many experts, diplomats and journalists.

item.title: Japan Might Revise Apology on Wartime Sex Slaves
item.description: An official hinted that the government might revise an official apology to women forced into sexual slavery during World War II, a move that would likely outrage South Korea.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Bennett Pushes Netanyahu Rightward
item.description: Naftali Bennett is not a serious contender to be Israel’s next prime minister, but his appealing biography and far-right platform could lure voters away from the Likud-Beiteinu ticket.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Naftali Bennett, campaigning Wednesday, has emerged as a pivotal figure in Israel’s elections.

item.title: Bolivia Makes Inroads Toward Reducing Coca Production
item.description: The nation is trying a nontraditional approach to eradicating coca production without violence and without the United States.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Former President’s Children Sue Lawmaker
item.description: Four children of an influential former Iranian president, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, are suing a lawmaker allied to the current president for describing their family as a corrupt “octopus.”
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Sunnis Continue Protests Against Prime Minister
item.description: Tens of thousands of Sunni Muslims blocked Iraq’s main trade route to neighboring Syria and Jordan in a demonstration on Wednesday against Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a Shiite.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mandela Is Released From the Hospital
item.description: Nelson Mandela, South Africa’s former president, was released from the hospital late Wednesday, ending a 19-day hospital stay.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN

item.title: New Delhi Journal: Indian City Overwhelmed by Air Pollution – New Delhi Journal
item.description: New Delhi has introduced policies aimed at improving air quality, but the efforts have not been able to keep up with population growth.
item.dc:creator: By NIHARIKA MANDHANA
item.media:description: The presidential palace was enveloped in smog on Nov. 3. New Delhi’s antipollution efforts have failed to keep up with growth.

item.title: Shinzo Abe Selected as Japan’s Prime Minister
item.description: Shinzo Abe returns to the helm as Japan faces the growing burden of its aging population, years of industrial decline and the challenge of an increasingly assertive China.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Shinzo Abe was selected as Japan's new prime minister in the lower house of Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: Public Release of Ozal Autopsy Urged in Turkey
item.description: The 1993 death of Turgut Ozal has for years been rumored to be the work of a militant group, and now one of his sons wants the full autopsy report published for public scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: United Arab Emirates Arrests Suspects in Terror Plots
item.description: Security forces arrested a cell made up of militants from Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, who were planning to carry out attacks in both countries and other states, the official news agency reported.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Morsi Admits Mistakes in Drafting Egypt’s Constitution
item.description: President Mohamed Morsi appealed for unity after the bitter debate over the Constitution, and he pledged to respect the one-third of voters who cast ballots against it.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Members of the Islamist-dominated upper house of the Egyptian Parliament met on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran Raises Level of Islamic Law Enforcement
item.description: A new directive prohibits all aircraft from flying across Iran during the call-to-prayer ritual, which is observed five times a day.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: In Gabon, Lure of Ivory Proves Hard to Resist
item.description: Gabon’s government has made efforts to combat poaching, but as the price of ivory soars its elephants are being slaughtered.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Gabon burned 10,000 pounds of ivory in June to show its commitment against poaching, but elephants are still being slaughtered.

item.title: Letter From Africa: South Africa Losing a Grip on Its Promise
item.description: With the first free elections in 1994, a new order under Nelson Mandela forged a new moral template. But the superlatives have shifted. Statistically, South Africa is the world's most unequal society.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In Soccer as in Life, Will a Resurgent Germany Dominate a Weakened Europe?
item.description: Germany's rise to dominate Europe on the economic front is clear, but the IHT's Nick Kulish reports that German might extends to an even more important realm: soccer.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: The Borussia Dortmund player Marco Reus, left, and Ajax player Daley Blind vie for the ball during the Champions League Group D soccer match in Amsterdam last month. Borussia won the match 4 to 1.
